item.title: JEE Advanced Maths Paper-2 | Question-2 | Detailed Solution
item.description: a step-by-step solution: Draw a diagram of the given configuration. Consider one of the smaller circles, say ğºğ‘–. Since it touches ğº externally, we have ğ‘Ÿ + ğ‘… = d, where d is the distance between the centers of ğºğ‘– and ğº. Now consider the two circles ğºğ‘– and ğºğ‘–+1. Since they also touch each other externally, we have ğ‘Ÿ + ğ‘Ÿ = d’, where d’ is the distance between the centers of ğºğ‘– and ğºğ‘–+1.

item.title: JEE Advanced Maths Paper-2 | Question-1 | Detailed Solution
item.description: The equation we are given can be written as: ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦âˆ’(ğ‘¦2âˆ’4ğ‘¦)ğ‘‘ğ‘¥=0 This is a first-order linear differential equation and can be solved using the integrating factor method. The integrating factor is ğ‘š=e^(âˆ«ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¥)=e^(x^2/2). We multiply both sides of the equation by the integrating factor to get: e^(x^2/2)ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦âˆ’e^(x^2/2)(ğ‘¦2âˆ’4ğ‘¦)ğ‘‘ğ‘¥=0 Now, we can integrate both sides of the equation to get: âˆ«e^(x^2/2)ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦âˆ’âˆ«e^(x^2/2)(ğ‘¦2âˆ’4ğ‘¦)ğ‘‘ğ‘¥=C After integration, we get: e^(x^2/2)y - 1/2e^(x^2/2)*(y^2 - 4y) = C Now, we can use the initial condition y(1) = 2 to solve for the constant C.

item.title: JEE Advanced Chemistry Paper-2 | Question-3 | Detailed Solution
item.description: The correct statement(s) about polymers is (A) The polymerization of chloroprene gives natural rubber, and (D) Ethene at 350-570 K temperature and 1000-2000 atm pressure in the presence of a peroxide initiator yields high density polythene. The polymerization of chloroprene (2-chlorobutadiene) does indeed give natural rubber, which is a type of elastomer. This process involves the addition polymerization of chloroprene monomers to form a polymer with a cis-1,4 configuration. Ethene (ethylene) can also be polymerized to form high density polyethylene (HDPE) using a peroxide initiator at high temperatures and pressures.

item.title: JEE Advanced Chemistry Paper-2 | Question-2 | Detailed Solution
item.description: To solve this problem, we can use the concept of molality, which is a measure of the concentration of a solute in a solvent. The molality of a solution is defined as the number of moles of solute per kilogram of solvent. In this case, the molality of the solution is 0.1 mol/1.8 kg = 0.0556 mol/kg. Since the salt remains 90% dissociated in the solution, this means that 0.9 Ã— 0.

item.title: JEE Advanced Chemistry Paper-2 | Question-1 | Detailed Solution
item.description: To solve this problem, we can use the solubility equilibrium expression for PbSO4: [Pb2+][SO4^2-] = Ksp We can also use the dissociation constants for sulfuric acid to write the equilibrium expressions for H2SO4 and SO4^2-: H2SO4 <=> H^+ + HSO4^- Ka1 = [H^+][HSO4^-]/[H2SO4] HSO4^- <=> H^+ + SO4^2- Ka2 = [H^+][SO4^2-]/[HSO4^-] We know that the concentration of H2SO4 is 1 M, and the concentration of Na2SO4 is 1.8 Ã— 10^-2 M.
